IRS Code 424 Meaning

IRS Code 424 is an early-stage examination request. It tells you that the IRS has pulled the return for possible audit. This page explains how to distinguish Code 424 from Code 420, what it signals about risk, and how to prepare clients in advance.

Try the parser (requires credits)

What Is IRS Code 424?

IRS Code 424 is typically described as an "Examination Request" or similar phrase. It indicates that the IRS has selected the return for potential examination based on internal scoring, referrals, or other criteria.

Think of Code 424 as the "heads-up" signal. It does not, by itself, tell you how deep the eventual audit will be, but it does tell you that the return is on the IRS's radar for closer review.

When Does Code 424 Appear on an IRS Transcript?

Code 424 can appear:

  • Shortly after filing, for returns selected quickly by scoring systems.
  • Months or years later, when a project or campaign targets older returns.
  • Before or alongside exam case codes like Code 420.

Reviewing the timing of 424 relative to Code 150 (Return Filed) and any Code 971 notices helps you understand when the IRS first focused on the year.

What Does Code 424 Usually Signal?

If Code 424 Appears Before Code 420

This is the most common sequence: 424 appears first as the selection, then 420 appears if an exam case is fully opened. In that pattern, 424 tells you the return was picked up, and 420 confirms the audit went forward.

If Code 424 Appears with Code 300 or 290

When 424 appears in the same timeframe as Code 300 or Code 290, it often marks the selection phase for an exam that eventually led to additional assessments. Your client-ready explanation should show how the selection under 424 evolved into dollars under 300/290.

If Code 424 Closes Without a Full Audit

Some 424 selections are closed without a full examination. You may see closing codes or simply no follow-up exam entries. Even then, the presence of 424 is a sign that the year attracted at least some additional IRS attention.

How IRS Selects Returns for Examination

While the exact scoring models are not public, selection can be based on DIF scores, information matching, issue-based campaigns, or referrals. Code 424 doesn't specify the reason, but it does tell you that the return cleared the threshold for potential exam activity.

What Should a Tax Professional Do When Code 424 Appears?

  • Review the return for obvious risk areas. High income, complex credits, or unusual patterns may be driving selection.
  • Prepare documentation. Begin organizing workpapers and source documents so you are ready if Code 420 appears or a notice arrives.
  • Educate the client. Calmly explain that the return has been flagged but that outcomes range from no-change to deficiency, depending on what the IRS reviews.

Example: Code 424 in a Parsed Transcript Report

In a parsed report, Code 424 will typically fall into an "Audit Signals" or "Examination Selection" section. The tool can highlight it alongside Codes 420 and 300 so you can narrate the full exam lifecycle.

Related IRS Transcript Codes

  • IRS Code 420 Meaning – Return selected for examination.
  • IRS Code 300 Meaning – Deficiency assessment after exam.
  • IRS Code 150 Meaning – Return filed and tax assessed.

FAQ: IRS Code 424

What does IRS Code 424 mean on a transcript?

It means the return has been selected for possible examination and moved into an examination request status.

How is Code 424 different from Code 420?

Code 424 is an early selection code; Code 420 marks an active exam case. They often appear in sequence.

Does Code 424 guarantee an audit?

No, some 424 selections are closed without full examination, but you should still treat it as an elevated risk signal.

What preparation should I start once I see Code 424?

Begin organizing documentation, issue summaries, and client communications so you are ready if the IRS proceeds to a full exam.
